comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content:
I dont think this plan was carried out, although they may have resumed the land. It shows a (proposed) railway station building on Hay Street which is now the north end of Belmore Park. If Gipps Street was an extension of Albion Street, that would run through Belmore Park too and become what is now Barlow Street. They ended up building the Station in the green (and yellow) area marked 4, south of Devonshire Street.
However it does show probably the main reason for constructing a railway station at this site; the much-forgotten proximity of Darling Harbour at this time, and transport of goods to international shipping.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
The plan wasn't carried out.

The map was prepared in 1849, some six years before the railway opened, (and fifty five before the line was extended) I have no doubt that there were many debates about the outcome. It was also prepared by the Sydney Railway Company, six years before Government took the company over.

There's no doubt Darling Harbour was in their thoughts, early plans had the line of road running closer to the harbour. The compromise was the Darling Harbour 'branch', which ran from Sydney station to the harbourside. 

One later proposal for 'central' station was to bring the line all the way into the city terminating at St James in Hyde Park. Another saw the terminal at Circular Quay.

Don Haggarty in his book "Sydney Railway - 1848 - 1857" (published 2005) has some interesting points to make on the subject of both the Darling Harbour branch and the various proposals for the location of the terminal station 

For example, as late as 15 March 1853 James Wallace - the railway's engineer still proposed the line be extended to Hay Street - but it was on 3 December that year that the Colonial Secretary wrote to the President of the Sydney Railway Company - Charles Cowper - that approved building the terminal in Cleveland Paddocks - ie south of the current station. As I said above it was fifty-five years before the station was to move to its current location, and still short of the Hay Street proposal. However, I am sure the former Directors of the SRC, had they lived to see Central Station,as built, would have been mightily impressed!

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Its curious that on this map, Regent Street is called George Street,  but on the other map,   Broadway is called George Street West.    That must have been confusing.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I dont think this map was made in 1849.    Why is it annotated "original station" near Cleveland Street.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/35179849@N08] You'll also notice that there is also a George Street (Redfern) shown. ... but the date of the map was 1849 ... there have been many renamings (and realignments) since then. As you suggest to avoid confusion.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: That part of Darling Harbour is under where Paddy's Market is  and it was a shallow swamp  and not a useful part of the harbour at all,   thats why it was filled in.   Quite a long walk from hay street to cockle bay now.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
Annotation at bottom right of plan

To accompany Engineer’s Report
of date November 30th 1849
Transmitted to the Honourable Colonial Secretary
with the application from the Director of the
Sydney Railway Company of 6th December 1939
Charles Cowper
-President

1939 ??

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/35179849@N08] Mitch, I know my gt-gt-grandfather's handwriting (and signature) well having read other letters of his and both in the family collection and on the public record. It most certainly is his writing! It could not possibly have been signed in 1939 ... Charles died in 1865! The annotation actuallys says '6th December 1849'. 

The map was laid before the Executive Council on 18 December 1849 and is signed by the Clerk of Council to verify this. (See annotation under Reference in the bottom centre of the map).

The map is annotated 'orginal station' because that was were the original station was planned to be and was located before the the location of Central Station was finalised.

comment.author: 60234040@N02

You're right I think the area now know as Hyde Park was a racecourse (or sorts) in the 1840s.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5207836758/]

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: "...From the very early days of the colony, the open area to the south east of the settlement was a favorite place for sport and recreation. It was known variously as 'The Common', the 'Exercising Ground', the 'Cricket Ground' and the 'Race Course...." dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/hyde_park

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content:
"...Only two days after Governor Macquarie dedicated Hyde Park for 'recreation and amusement' it became the site of Australia's first official horse race meeting organised on 15, 17 and 19 October 1810 by the officers of the 73rd Regiment (Macquarie's regiment). The meetings to devise the rules and organise the event were held in the officers' mess and many of the horses were owned by the officers. 

The race meeting consisted of a series of heats with weights set depending on the sex and age of a horse. There were also a number of match races between two horses and sweepstake prizes offered. Governor Macquarie himself attended each day of the meeting. This format for race meetings was followed in the colony for the next 50 years. Owners mostly rode their own horses and the courses were marked by flags and posts. Novelty events were often included.

Meetings continued to be held at Hyde Park up until the formation of the Sydney Turf Club in 1825 when they were moved to the 'Bellevue' course. Meetings were also run at Parramatta and Camperdown. The Australian Racing and Jockey Club was formed in 1828 with the encouragement of Governor Darling but the colony could not support two race clubs and both folded in 1831..." wiki
